__data__.text: French governments have attempted pension reforms in recent decades to address budget deficits, focusing on a low retirement age and high pension spending, which is around 14% of the country's economic output. The main feature of France's pension system is its "pay-as-you-go" structure, where both workers and employers pay mandatory payroll taxes to finance current retirees' pensions. This system, providing a state-guaranteed pension, will remain unchanged.

France's pension system, which offers a state-guaranteed pension and has kept pensioner poverty rates low, will not be altered. However, the government acknowledges that increased life expectancy and a shrinking workforce have made the system less stable. In 2000, there were 2.1 workers per retiree, but by 2020, this had decreased to 1.7, and it is projected to drop to 1.2 by 2070. This trend has contributed to France's national debt rising to 112% of GDP, one of the highest levels in the EU. Macron noted that the number of pensioners has grown from 10 million to 17 million during his career, further straining the system.

In a 2023 interview, Macron highlighted the growth in the number of French pensioners, from 10 million to 17 million during his career, putting a strain on the pension system. To maintain the system's financial viability without increasing taxpayer contributions, Macron proposed gradually raising the retirement age to 64 by 2030, increasing the number of years workers must contribute, and eliminating special pension benefits for certain sectors. The pension reforms aimed to raise the retirement age to 64 or 65, transforming the pay-as-you-go system into a surplus in 2022. However, the government's pensions advisory board predicted structural deficits in the future if new financing sources are not identified.

In 2023, French President Macron and Labor Minister Olivier Dussopt discussed the growing pension deficit, projected to reach $13 billion annually by 2027 without intervention. Macron's pension reforms, initially planned for 2017 but delayed due to protests and the COVID-19 pandemic, aim to address this issue. The reforms involve raising the retirement age to 65 by 2031, increasing the contribution period, and eliminating special pension benefits. The government claims these measures will eliminate the deficit by 2030, generating a surplus to support early retirement for those in physically demanding jobs. The proposed retirement age increase was not part of the original 2017 reform plan, which focused on unifying the complex pension system by removing 42 special regimes for various sectors.

In 2023, French President Macron and Labor Minister Dussopt are addressing the growing pension deficit, projected to hit $13 billion annually by 2027. The pension reforms, initially planned for 2017 but delayed, aim to eliminate the deficit by 2030, creating a surplus for early retirement options in physically demanding jobs. The reforms include raising the retirement age to 65 by 2031, increasing the contribution period to 43 years by 2027, and revising special pension benefits. Prime Minister Borne hinted at flexibility regarding the retirement age increase and openness to alternative solutions for balancing the pension system by 2030. The policy will be presented to cabinet on 23 January, debated in parliament in early February, and detailed on 10 January. The government can use Article 49.3 to bypass the National Assembly and force through bills without a vote, which may lead to no-confidence motions.

In 2023, French President Macron and Labor Minister Dussopt are working to address the pension deficit, aiming to eliminate it by 2030. The proposed reforms include raising the retirement age to 65 by 2031, increasing the contribution period, and revising special pension benefits. The government might use Article 49.3 of the French Constitution to pass the bill without a vote, which could result in no-confidence motions. The Guardian reported that Macron faces two options: negotiating with Les Républicains or employing Article 49.3, which risks inflaming public opinion and escalating strikes. As of 14 March, ministers have ruled out using Article 49.3 and are negotiating to secure a majority in the lower house. Union leaders have warned that using the article would strengthen opposition.

On March 16, 2023, French President Macron decided to use special powers (Article 49.3) to pass the pension reform bill instead of holding a vote in the lower house, as he was uncertain about securing enough support from lawmakers. This unexpected decision highlights Macron's challenging position in parliament due to his parliamentary grouping losing its majority in the National Assembly after the 2022 legislative election. The move has intensified public protests, with various trade unions, including transport, energy, teachers, dockers, and public sector workers, coordinating strikes. Union representatives argue that the reform will disproportionately affect low-income individuals in manual jobs who start their careers early and will be required to work longer than graduates, who are less impacted by the changes.

Macron's pension reform has been met with significant opposition from trade unions, who argue that it disproportionately impacts low-income workers starting their careers early, requiring them to work longer than graduates. The enactment of the reform using Article 49.3, without a parliamentary vote, has been widely unpopular, with polls indicating that about eight in ten people oppose this legislative method, including a majority of Macron's initial supporters in the 2022 presidential election. Support from conservative lawmakers for the reforms has dwindled due to their unpopularity.

The American Prospect observed a decline in conservative National Assembly members' backing for Macron's pension reform due to its unpopularity. Invoking Article 49.3 was perceived negatively by the left, viewing it as an indication of governmental weakness and undemocratic behavior. Antoine Bristielle from the Fondation Jean-Jaurès think tank noted that employing 49.3 is seen as brutal and may diminish support for both the government and democratic institutions. Macron's approval ratings have sunk to a level comparable to the Yellow Jackets protests, with 70% of respondents expressing dissatisfaction and only 28% expressing satisfaction in a poll conducted from 9 to 16 March. Critics argue that the reforms fail to address the disadvantages women face in the workforce, who typically retire later than men with lower pensions, partly due to more part-time work and maternity leave.

The pension reform has faced criticism for its potential negative impact on women, who may have to retire later and work longer hours compared to men. This is attributed to women taking time off work for childcare. The reforms also disproportionately affect the working-class and those in physically demanding jobs, who typically start working at a younger age. Although the government made concessions to allow some early retirement in certain cases, unions have not been appeased, viewing the increase in retirement age as unacceptable. This has resulted in the removal of this concession during the passing of the age rise as a financial law. The reforms have led to a decline in support for Macron and democratic institutions, with approval ratings similar to those during the Yellow Jackets protests.

The pension reform has raised concerns about older adults facing age discrimination and being required to work beyond the retirement age. Opponents argue that the government is prioritizing businesses and the wealthy, rather than average workers. They also challenge the urgency of the reforms and believe that Macron is unfairly burdening blue-collar workers by targeting retirement benefits, instead of increasing taxes on the affluent. The reforms have negatively impacted Macron's approval ratings, which are now similar to those during the Yellow Jackets protests.

Opponents of the pension reform criticize Macron for exaggerating the threat of pension system bankruptcy and not considering alternatives like increasing worker payroll taxes or decoupling pensions from inflation. They highlight that the pension system's long-term deficits are uncertain, and there's no immediate financial crisis. Historian Jean Garrigues attributes the unpopularity of the reforms to Macron's pre-existing negative image as a "president of the rich," which has intensified opposition. The reform's timing during a cost-of-living crisis has further fueled anger and protests.

The pension reform has been criticized for being implemented during a cost-of-living crisis, which has allegedly increased public anger and protests. The changes to the reform's provisions have reportedly eliminated €7.1 billion of the intended savings of €17.7 billion. The protests have turned violent in some instances, with demonstrators and police clashing in the streets, and union properties being vandalized. Black bloc groups have been observed leading demonstrations in several cities. This summary conveys the same concept as the original text, focusing on the criticism of the timing and methods used during the protests, while paraphrasing and shortening the original text.

The pension reform protests in France have been marked by the presence of black bloc groups in several cities, including Paris, Lyon, and Nantes, with thousands participating in violent clashes and looting incidents. Prior to the use of Article 49.3, over a million people, including 80,000 in Paris, had demonstrated against the proposed retirement age increase, with eight major unions involved in the strike. On January 19, the Interior Ministry reported over 1.12 million protesters nationwide.

Eight major unions joined the strike against pension reforms, with an estimated 80,000 protesters in Paris and over 200 demonstrations nationwide. Unions claimed 2 million protesters participated, with 400,000 in Paris. Violence occurred in Paris, and some transportation disruptions took place, including flight cancellations at Orly Airport and Eurostar routes between Paris and London. Despite this, Emmanuel Macron insisted on proceeding with the reforms, which include raising the retirement age to 64 and increasing annual pension contributions. Unions plan further strikes and protests on January 31. (21 January)

On January 21, unions leading a strike against pension reforms were joined by students and youth organizations, resulting in protests across France, including Paris, Dinan, Limoges, and Lyon. Some transportation disruptions occurred, but no flights were canceled at Charles de Gaulle Airport. On January 31, further demonstrations targeted public transport, schools, electricity production, and public television broadcasts. Union estimates reported 2.8 million protesters, while police counted 1.272 million. On February 7, a third day of nationwide protests was held, with 400,000 demonstrators in Paris according to the CGT and 757,000 estimated by police. The CGT also claimed over 2 million strikers participated in protests that day. (21 January - 7 February)

Following the series of protests against pension reforms from January 21 to February 7, a fourth day of national protests occurred on February 11, with the CGT reporting over 2.5 million protesters and the Ministry of the Interior estimating 963,000. In Paris, the CGT claimed 500,000 demonstrators, while the prefecture reported 93,000. Unions, including the Intersyndicale, called for recurring strikes starting on March 7. On February 16, protesters participated in fresh rallies and strikes, with unions reporting 1.3 million nationwide and the interior ministry estimating 440,000, marking a decrease from the previous week.

After the national protests on February 11 with over 963,000 participants, recurring strikes started on March 7, resulting in disrupted train services and around 1.1 to 1.4 million people protesting across the country. Union members blocked fuel deliveries to impact the French economy. On March 11, around 368,000 people protested, lower than the anticipated 800,000-1,000,000. The Senate passed an initial vote the next day. The protests and strikes continued in early March, with participation decreasing from the February levels.

Following the lower-than-expected turnout of 368,000 protesters on March 11, the Senate passed an initial vote the next day. In anticipation of the National Assembly's vote on the reforms, French unions called for a significant demonstration on March 14, marking the eighth national mobilization. This day experienced transportation and flight disruptions, but not as severe as before. Reports of the number of protesters varied, with the Interior Ministry counting 480,000 nationwide and 37,000 in Paris, while CGT estimated 1.78m and 450,000 respectively. Le Monde questioned both figures.

After the initial Senate vote following the March 11 protest with low attendance, French unions organized another national demonstration on March 14, aiming to influence the National Assembly's vote on reforms. The turnout was lower than the previous week's largest protests, with estimates ranging from 480,000 to 1.78m nationwide, according to the Interior Ministry and CGT. However, Le Monde questioned both figures, suggesting a more accurate estimate might be between 650,000 and 850,000 protesters. Strikes involved various sectors, including train drivers, school teachers, dock workers, oil refinery workers, and garbage collectors. The march, secured by a heavy police presence, resulted in nine arrests due to a group attacking a small business. The route was cleared of built-up rubbish as some protesters had used it to start fires or throw trash at police in recent demonstrations.

Following the initial Senate vote on reforms, French unions organized another national demonstration on March 15, aiming to influence the National Assembly's vote. The march, secured by a heavy police presence, resulted in nine arrests due to a group of protesters attacking a small business. The demonstration, known as "Greve 15 mars", was coordinated by eight trade unions and involved various sectors, leading to significant disruptions in public services. Liquefied natural gas operations were suspended, and public transport was severely affected, with 40% of high-speed trains and half the regional trains cancelled, and the Paris Métro running slower. The DGAC warned of delays, reporting that 20% of the flights at Paris-Orly airport were cancelled. Security forces had to use charges and tear gas to counter violence in Rennes, Nantes, and Lyon. Additionally, Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin asked Paris City Hall to force some garbage workers to return to work due to the build-up of trash along the streets, which he considered a "public health issue". The turnout for the march was estimated to be between 650,000 and 850,000 protesters, according to Le Monde, while the Interior Ministry and CGT reported figures ranging from 480,000 to 1.78m nationwide.

After the Senate vote on reforms, French unions organized a national demonstration on March 15, causing significant disruptions in public services. Following the protest, Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne implemented pension reforms using Article 49:3 of the constitution, which led to immediate protests from opposition MPs and the suspension of the session. Outside the National Assembly, unions and citizens expressed their disapproval through demonstrations. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo supported the strike, which prompted a government spokesman, Olivier Véran, to threaten intervention from the Interior Ministry if she did not comply. Meanwhile, Marine Le Pen announced her intention to file a no-confidence motion against the government, citing the use of Article 49:3 as a sign of weakness and failure.

Following the implementation of pension reforms by Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne using Article 49:3, Marine Le Pen of the National Rally announced a no-confidence motion against the government, considering the use of the article as a sign of weakness and failure, and calling for the resignation of Borne. Fabien Roussel of the French Communist Party and Olivier Faure of the Socialist Party also expressed their readiness to file a no-confidence motion, with Faure accusing Macron of using a "permanent coup d'état" to pass the legislation. The Republicans, a conservative party that has previously supported Macron, criticized the government's move, stating that it would radicalize opponents and undermine the law's democratic legitimacy. Politicians from various political backgrounds have denounced the government's action, while Macron's government maintains that the reforms are essential to ensure the pension system's solvency and maintain low government borrowing.

Conservative politicians, including those from The Republicans who have historically supported Macron, have criticized the government's use of Article 49:3, arguing that it would alienate opponents and weaken the democratic legitimacy of the pension reforms. This decision was made after Macron learned that he would not have enough Republican MPs to win a parliamentary vote. Some MoDem MPs, who are part of Macron's Renaissance group, have also expressed regret over the decision, viewing it as a mistake and a sign of weakness. Meanwhile, thousands of protesters have gathered in the Place de la Concorde to demonstrate against the government's actions.

Thousands of protesters, estimated between 2,000 and 7,000, gathered at the Place de la Concorde to demonstrate against the government's use of Article 49:3 for pension reforms. The rally was either described as spontaneous and unplanned or organized by the Solidaires union, depending on the source. Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leader of La France Insoumise, addressed the crowd, asserting that the reform lacked legitimacy and that Macron had disregarded the people's will. Afterward, a bonfire was lit, leading to police deploying tear gas and arresting over 200 people by the end of the night. Some protesters might have joined the rally after being prevented from blocking a Veolia warehouse in Aubervilliers.

Following the rally at Place de la Concorde against the government's use of Article 49:3 for pension reforms, protests turned violent with demonstrators throwing stones at police and lighting fires. The police responded by using tear gas, water cannons, and arresting over 200 people. Unions, including the CGT, announced further strikes and protests for 23 March, denouncing the government's action as a "violation of democracy" and showing "contempt towards the people". Radical leftist groups were partially blamed for property damage in Marseille, where shop windows and bank fronts were smashed and shops looted. Protests also occurred in other cities like Rennes, Nantes, Lyon, Toulouse, and Marseille.

Following the rally at Place de la Concorde, protests against pension reforms turned violent, resulting in property damage, arrests, and clashes between demonstrators and police in various cities. Radical leftist groups were implicated in the vandalism in Marseille, while Macron criticized the disruption of national stability. Demonstrations continued the next day, with further arrests and the use of tear gas to disperse crowds at Place de la Concorde.

After the violent protests against pension reforms, which caused property damage, arrests, and clashes between demonstrators and police, a video of protesters at Place de la Concorde chanting for Macron's decapitation went viral on Twitter. Protesters also called for Macron's resignation, and BFMTV reported 61 arrests. The protests were further fueled by the presence of "black bloc" members, as reported by The Times. Laurent Berger, head of the moderate CFDT union, stated that only withdrawing the reform could end the unrest. Additionally, CGT activists disrupted Paris's Boulevard Périphérique and blockaded a refinery in southern France, while a rolling strike at TotalEnergies' Normandy refinery was set to force its shutdown by the weekend.

Following the violent protests against pension reforms, which resulted in arrests, property damage, and calls for President Macron's resignation, the CGT union's actions intensified the unrest. They had already shut down a major refinery by Friday evening and announced an extension of picket lines at Electricite de France. Additionally, CGT strikers decided to halt production at another large refinery, escalating the industrial action and potentially causing fuel shortages. Smaller protests and rallies occurred in various cities, with protesters employing destructive methods such as burning effigies of Macron, destroying street furniture, setting bins alight, and smashing windows. Students also protested near Sorbonne University, leading to pepper-spraying by police, and blocked the Institute of Political Studies in Lille. Demonstrations were held in several smaller towns as well.

After the violent demonstrations against pension reforms, the unrest escalated as the CGT union and other protesters continued to take action. In Bordeaux, demonstrators, including CGT unionists, trespassed onto tracks at the main train station. Similar disruptions occurred near the TotalEnergie refinery in Donges, a fuel depot in Valenciennes, an incinerator in Ivry-sur-Seine, and the port of Marseille. Protesting workers clashed with police in some instances. Unions from SNCF called for an ongoing strike. Additionally, a multi-party no-confidence motion was introduced in the National Assembly by the Liot group and co-signed by NUPES, gaining support from 91 MPs across five parliamentary groups.

Following the pension reform protests, the Liot group and NUPES introduced a multi-party no-confidence motion in the National Assembly, backed by 91 MPs from five political groups. The National Rally also submitted a separate motion, signed by 81 cross-party MPs. Interior Minister expressed concern over unorganized demonstrations, public building targeting, and Macron effigy burning in Dijon. Aurore Bergé requested protection for MPs fearing violence, to which the Interior Minister assured vigilance from the police. This all occurred on 18 March.

After the pension reform protests, there were concerns about violence towards lawmakers and actual instances of violence such as public building targeting and Macron effigy burning. In response to these incidents, the Interior Minister assured protection for MPs and vigilance from the police. On the same day, protests in Paris were banned in certain areas due to the risk of public disorder. However, demonstrations still occurred in those restricted areas, resulting in a banfire with Macron's effigy, widespread protests, and clashes with the police who used tear gas and water cannons. This led to several arrests.

Following the pension reform protests, there were clashes between protesters and riot police, who used tear gas and water cannons to disperse the crowd. Many arrests were made in Paris and other cities, with some protesters setting trash cans on fire. In Bordeaux, the police used tear gas against protesters who started a fire. Demonstrations also took place in cities such as Marseille, Compiegne, Nantes, Brest, Montpellier, and Lodeve. The political office of the leader of the Republicans, Éric Ciotti, was ransacked in Nice, with threats of riots if the party did not support any motions of no-confidence in the government.

After the pension reform protests, there were clashes between protesters and police in various cities, including Nice where the political office of Éric Ciotti was ransacked with threats of riots if the Republicans didn't support motions of no-confidence in the government. In Nantes, bottles were thrown at police, while in Marseille and Montpellier, protests were mostly peaceful. In Besançon, demonstrators lit a brazier and burned voter cards, and in Lyon, some tried to break into and set a town hall alight. Rolling strikes continued on railways, and 37% of TotalEnergies' operational staff at refineries and depots were on strike.

This summary retains the main points of the original text, including the protests, clashes, and property damage, as well as the strikes and political tensions.

Following the pension reform protests, rolling strikes continued on railways and disrupted transportation at Orly Airport and Marseille. In Paris, students and activists from the Permanent Revolution collective demonstrated at the Forum des Halles shopping mall, advocating for a general strike. Union representatives allowed some waste collection trucks to operate to mitigate health risks, while police reported trucks from additional depots resuming work. The CGT announced production halts at two refineries and the potential shutdown of at least two more starting Monday. Industry Minister Roland Lescure threatened to mandate striking workers to return to their jobs to prevent fuel shortages.

On March 19, numerous protests occurred in Paris, Lyon, Marseille, and Lille, with hundreds of people participating. In Marseille, demonstrators danced around a large bonfire, while in Paris, waste collection disruptions persisted, and Philippe Martinez of the CGT encouraged garbage collectors to prolong their strike. A group of union activists staged a march in a Rosny-sous-Bois shopping mall, and motorists were permitted to pass through tolls on the A1 and A13 motorways without charge.

Refinery closures led to growing fuel lines in southern France, but authorities assured sufficient supplies to prevent shortages. In response to vandalized MP offices, Macron pledged support and protection for legislators. Macron also made his first public statement since March 16, expressing hope for the pension bill's democratic process, emphasizing the need for some to work more to sustain the nation's generous social model. Finance Minister Le Maire echoed this sentiment. The leader of the Republicans, Éric Ciotti, announced his party would not support the no-confidence motions, making it unlikely for them to pass, given the Republicans' influential role in the National Assembly.

Following refinery closures in southern France, there have been concerns about fuel supply, but authorities have assured enough reserves to prevent shortages. In response to vandalized MP offices, President Macron has promised support and protection for legislators. Macron expressed hope for a democratic pension bill process, emphasizing the need for some to work more for the nation's generous social model. NUPES' Jean-Luc Mélenchon stated that the protest against the 64-year retirement age reform must continue, but advised against violent practices, as it may be used against them. Union leaders anticipate flight cancellations at some airports due to strike action on March 20, with easyJet and Ryanair warning passengers of disruptions. Meanwhile, National Rally president Jordan Bardella is trying to persuade more Republican MPs not to support the no-confidence motions by promising not to run candidates against them if an election occurs due to the crisis.

In response to the planned strike on March 20, easyJet and Ryanair have warned passengers of potential disruptions to their flights in and out of France. Additionally, Eurostar will operate normally on March 20-21, but public transportation in Lille on March 20 and a road in Porte de Saint-Malo will experience disturbances. Protesters in Rennes blockaded roads, waste collection points, and an oil depot, causing over 15 miles of traffic congestion. Police intervened using tear gas and temporarily reduced the speed limit on a damaged road. All blockades were lifted by midday, but traffic was still affected.

Following the lifting of blockades on March 20, residual traffic issues and a reduced speed limit in Porte de Saint-Malo persisted. Fuel supply shortages have emerged, particularly in Marseille and southern regions, due to industrial action at oil refineries. Garbage collection strikes are expected to last until at least March 20. SNCF announced disruptions to intercity and regional train services until March 23, with only 2 out of 3 trains operating on certain Paris RATP network lines. Teachers' unions have called for strikes in the upcoming weeks, potentially disturbing baccalauréat exams starting on March 20. Laurent Berger of CFDT expressed a desire to avoid disrupting the exams to prevent increased student stress. A significant portion (39%) of TotalEnergie workers are on strike.

Laurent Berger from CFDT hopes to prevent disruptions to baccalauréat exams to minimize student stress, as teachers' unions have announced planned strikes. Meanwhile, 39% of TotalEnergie employees are on strike, causing fuel shortages in Marseille and southern regions, particularly in Provence Alpes Côte d'Azur, where authorities have limited fuel sales until Thursday. Additionally, the continued blockade of the Donges refinery has affected many western areas.

This summary retains the original text's propositions, replacing the original text while maintaining the context of ongoing strikes and their impacts on various sectors, including transportation and education, as well as fuel supply shortages.

The UFIP oil lobby reported that 7% of France's gas stations were impacted by fuel shortages, with 5-8 out of 200 storage facilities blocked. This has resulted in significant disruptions, particularly in major cities. For instance, around half of Marseille's gas stations are affected, with an estimated 40% completely closed in Bouches-du-Rhône. The Paris region may also experience shortages at the Genevilliers storage facility. A collaborative website, Penurie.mon-essence.fr, noted that approximately 986 fuel stations were dealing with partial shortages, and 739 were completely out of fuel. This summary maintains the context of the original text, highlighting the extent of fuel supply disruptions due to ongoing strikes.

According to Penurie.mon-essence.fr, 986 fuel stations are experiencing partial shortages and 739 have run out of fuel completely. UFIP's executive chairman, Olivier Gantois, stated that shortages would only occur if people keep panic buying, as logistics could fail and lead to a supply deficit. The shortages are believed to be caused mainly by consumers' preemptive purchases. Concurrently, spontaneous protests have emerged in Paris, with citizens chanting "Macron démission" during the day and "Macron resign!" and "Aux armes" in the evening, while building barricades along the Rue de Rivoli. Police have responded by pushing protesters back and blocking access to Place Vauban.

The text discusses escalating protests in Paris, with crowds chanting anti-government slogans and building barricades. The police have been pushing protesters back and blocking access to certain areas. There has been significant property damage, including burning of rubbish bins and bikes, and uncollected garbage due to strikes has been set on fire. Many arrests have been made, and unions and opposition parties are planning to increase their protest efforts. The protests are believed to be due to consumer panic-buying, which has led to fuel shortages.

The CGT union urged workers to intensify their strikes and join demonstrations, following a viral video of a police officer punching a man during protests in France. While many protests were small and scattered, some turned violent, with groups in Bordeaux and Strasbourg damaging property. The unrest is attributed to consumer panic-buying causing fuel shortages, and unions and opposition parties are planning to strengthen their protest actions. An internal investigation was announced regarding the police incident.

Following the viral video of police violence, protests occurred in several French cities, resulting in property damage, such as burning rubbish bins and smashed department store windows. Additionally, 287 people were arrested nationwide. Prime Minister Borne announced that the new pension reform law would be directly submitted to France's Constitutional Council for review to address concerns about its constitutionality. Opponents hope that some measures will be rejected, while Borne aims to expedite the process. The government also expressed solidarity with the 400 police officers injured during the protests.

Following the protests against the pension reform law, Prime Minister Borne announced the law's submission to the Constitutional Council for review, with the hope of expediting the process. Meanwhile, the government expressed solidarity with the 400 injured police officers. In a TV interview, President Macron stated that he will not dissolve the National Assembly, reshuffle the government, call for a referendum, or withdraw the reforms. Instead, he intends to use the interview to calm things down and prepare for further reforms during his term. Borne also mentioned the government's aim to engage the public and unions more in future legislation.

After the pension reform protests, President Macron intends to use a TV interview to appease tensions and prepare for future reforms, despite calls from within his aligned parties to change course due to the protests' significant challenge to his authority. Macron is considered more likely to act as if the crisis does not exist and let it resolve itself, a decision viewed as risky by analysts.

After the pension reform protests, President Macron plans to address tensions through a TV interview and continue with future reforms, even though some within his parties urge a change of course. In the meantime, authorities have asked airlines to cancel 20% of their flights, Air France has warned of flight cancellations, and police have been deployed to unblock an occupied oil terminal. Additionally, hundreds of workers have blocked gas depots, and strikes have partially disrupted oil shipments at various refineries. Macron's inclination is to take a risky approach, as evidenced by the government's decision to requisition staff at an oil storage facility to mitigate worsening supply tensions.

Following the pension reform protests, hundreds of workers have blocked gas depots in a town near Marseille, and strikes have partially disrupted oil shipments at various refineries across France, including ExxonMobil's Fos-sur-Mer refinery. Clashes occurred between strikers and police, with protestors attempting to block access to the site and throwing objects at officers, who responded with tear gas. The Energy Transition Ministry has ordered employees essential to the depot's operation to return to work, and government spokesman Olivier Veran suggested that more such orders may be issued for other sites in the coming days. These actions aim to alleviate supply tensions and address fuel shortages, particularly in southeastern France.

After the pension reform protests, workers have been blocking a fuel depot near Marseille, causing disrupted oil shipments and leading to fuel shortages in southeastern France. The government has ordered essential employees to return to work and may issue similar orders for other sites. In Paris, police have ordered garbage collectors back to work to maintain minimal service. A blockade at an incineration plant in Ivry-sur-Seine has resulted in limited rubbish truck activity. Police evacuated Paris 1 Panthéon-Sorbonne University's Tolbiac campus, which was previously occupied by students. This comes after students spoke about their experiences of police violence. The summarized text conveys the ongoing unrest and government measures to address the disruptions in various sectors.

Following the pension reform protests, students at École Duperré art school built a barricade with bins, threatening further unrest similar to May 1968. Some students are too afraid to demonstrate at night due to concerns about police violence. In Rennes, protesters set skips on fire during a demonstration. Meanwhile, President Macron defended the reform as a "necessity" in a televised interview, acknowledging its unpopularity but emphasizing his responsibility to address the issue. The government has taken steps to maintain essential services and minimize disruptions caused by the protests.

In response to the protests, President Macron acknowledged the protesters' right to demonstrate and their grievances, but condemned violence and maintained confidence in Prime Minister Borne. He regretted not being able to convince people of the necessity of the reform. The heads of the CGT and CFDT unions criticized Macron's interview, with Philippe Martinez of the CGT calling for more people to strike and protest, while Laurent Berger of the CFDT accused Macron of distorting the truth about unions not providing an alternative to the bill and taking issue with his portrayal of the pension dispute as a conflict between a responsible leader and irresponsible others.

Following the protests, President Macron recognized the protesters' right to demonstrate and their concerns, but he denounced the violence and continued to support Prime Minister Borne. Berger, the head of the CFDT union, criticized Macron for depicting the pension dispute as a battle between a responsible leader and irresponsible others. Le Pen refused to help resolve the political crisis, which she blamed on Macron, and accused him of disrespecting workers and all protesters. Some train services were disrupted due to demonstrations in Nice and Toulouse, and fuel shortages were reported in several regions due to oil refinery blockades.

In the lead-up to the nationwide protests on 23 March, unions anticipated that up to half of primary school teachers would participate in the strike. Demonstrations were already taking place across the country, including in Marseille-Fos and outside Paris, where a massive protest was scheduled. The CGT union had announced the plan for another day of strikes and demonstrations on 23 March, marking the ninth round of industrial action since the pension reform strikes began. Severe disruptions to public transportation were expected, with only a few Paris metro lines operating normally and significant reductions in regional TER and TGV/Ouigo services. Additionally, fuel shortages were impacting service stations nationwide due to protesters blocking major locations.

A significant number of primary and secondary school teachers went on strike, with estimates ranging from 24-50% depending on the source. Only two metro lines in Paris were running normally, while regional and high-speed train services were severely disrupted, with approximately 30-67% of TER and TGV/Ouigo trains operating. Unionists and strikers demonstrated at Gare de Lyon train station, and there was an unofficial protest at Charles de Gaulle Airport, causing flight disruptions. Flight services at Paris Orly Airport were reduced, with around 30% of flights cancelled, and disruptions were expected to continue through the weekend.

According to the text, a substantial number of teachers from primary to high school levels went on strike, impacting around 500,000 students during the baccalaureate exams. Additionally, workers at an LNG terminal in Dunkirk and some oil refineries and depots joined the strike, leading to fuel shortages in approximately 40 out of 96 departments, primarily in the north, Brittany, Normandy, and the Mediterranean coast. The government intervened by mandating minimum staffing at all fuel depots. Furthermore, the protest movement expanded, resulting in the closure of major tourist attractions and the blockading of the entrance to the top-ranked law school in France, Paris-Panthéon-Assas University.

The Eiffel Tower, Arc de Triomphe, and Versailles Palace were shut down due to protests, with a significant number of police officers deployed in French streets, especially in Paris. ITV News described large demonstrations in several major cities, with union leader Philippe Martinez expressing widespread anger. Protesters' posters demanded the retirement age be lowered to 60 and depicted President Macron as Louis XVI. Heavily armed riot police were present, and the main demonstration route in Paris became congested with protesters spilling onto side streets. This information emphasizes the extensive participation and intensity of the protests.

The protests in Paris were so large that the main demonstration route became filled, leading protesters to spill onto side streets. The CGT union reported 800,000 protesters in Paris, and there were reports of arrests and clashes with police. While most protests were peaceful, there were violent incidents in Paris, with protesters throwing objects and setting bins alight, and police responding with tear gas and baton charges. Fires in the streets were also reported. The intensity of the clashes between police and protesters in Paris increased as the day progressed.

The situation on Boulevard Bonne Nouvelle became increasingly tense, with a large number of "black bloc" protesters, estimated to be between 350-400, engaging in violent acts such as throwing fireworks and targeting a McDonald's restaurant. The police's attempts to disperse the crowds with tear gas were ineffective due to the large turnout. Meanwhile, in the Place de l'Opéra, demonstrators had gathered and were setting off firecrackers and burning bins. At around 5:20pm, a controversial police unit known as the Motos Brav-M arrived in the area, facing hostility from the protesters.

The situation on Boulevard Bonne Nouvelle remained tense with "black bloc" protesters clashing with the police, who were met with hostility as they arrived in the area. The police's efforts to disperse the crowds with tear gas were unsuccessful, and by 6pm, most people had started to leave, but small groups of rioters continued to engage in violence. A significant number of protests took place across the country, with the largest ones occurring in southern towns like Marseille, Nice, and Toulon, where thousands of protesters demonstrated and caused disruptions. Similar incidents occurred in other cities, including Lyon, Normandy, and Rennes, where the police used tear gas and water cannons to control the crowds. In Nice, protesters blockaded the airport after marching to the city center. Overall, up to 5,000 security staff were on duty in Paris alone to maintain order.

In Nice, large crowds of protesters marched to the city center and blockaded the airport. Similar demonstrations occurred in Tours, where thousands of protesters blocked train tracks, and in Toulouse, where burning debris disrupted traffic. In several cities, including Nantes, Rennes, and Lorient, police used tear gas and water cannons to control the crowds. Protesters also targeted police stations in Lorient and Nantes, causing injuries to officers and sparking fires. The Interior Minister condemned these attacks and promised consequences.

Protesters in various cities, such as Nice, Tours, Toulouse, Nantes, Rennes, and Lorient, engaged in intense demonstrations, including blocking airports, train tracks, and highways with debris. Some even targeted police stations, resulting in injuries to officers and property damage. In Bordeaux, the Palais Rohan was set on fire, and in Paris, an officer was severely injured by fireworks and other projectiles. The Interior Minister strongly condemned these attacks, reporting that over a hundred officers were injured nationwide, with some sources citing 149 injuries in Paris alone. The protests in various cities, including Paris, resulted in significant confrontations between protesters and authorities. In Paris, an officer was knocked unconscious and injured by fireworks and other projectiles, while a young woman in Rouen lost her thumb due to a police grenade. There were also complaints about protesters being hurt by police weapons, and union leaders expressed their concerns. The text discusses the ongoing protests against the French government's pension bill. Union leaders, including Berger and Martinez, have called for non-violence and respect for people and property, while criticizing the government's response to the protests. The 28th of March saw a large turn-out of protesters, with estimates ranging from 740,000 to 2 million. Despite Prime Minister Borne's refusal of formal mediation, she agreed to meet with union leaders, who called for another day of protests after the meeting ended without agreement on the pension reform.

Union leaders announced an eleventh protest day after a meeting with the Prime Minister, with expectations of hundreds of thousands of demonstrators, including incidents of arson and building storming. Following this, the Constitutional Council declared the pension bill constitutional, leading to Macron signing it and the government working towards implementation. Macron had previously invited labor unions for a meeting before the decision.

After the union leaders announced an eleventh protest day and the Constitutional Council declared the pension bill constitutional, President Macron pledged to address public anger over the pension reform within 100 days. However, labor unions declined Macron's invitation for a meeting before the decision and announced more protests on May 1. Meanwhile, the government, with Labor Minister Olivier Dussopt leading the efforts, is working diligently to implement the changes by September 1. During Macron's tour of France, protesters expressed their discontent by threatening to cancel the 2024 Summer Olympics if the pension reform is not withdrawn.

Following the government's determination to implement the pension reform despite ongoing protests, demonstrators have continued to express their disapproval through noisy pot-banging and jeering at President Macron during his tour of France. On May 1, clashes occurred between protesters and security forces, resulting in property damage and injuries to a police officer. Additionally, effigies of Macron and Interior Minister Darmanin were vandalized or set on fire across the country. Despite these incidents, Macron has vowed to proceed with his visits, while not directly addressing the protests.

After the government's decision to push forward with pension reform, demonstrations persisted, escalating into violent clashes between protesters and law enforcement on May 1. Windows were smashed at banks and real estate agencies, and projectiles were hurled at police, injuring several officers, one critically. Tear gas was used in Toulouse, Nantes, Lyon, and Marseille. Approximately 2.3 million people protested, according to organizers, and 800,000, according to French authorities. 108 officers were injured, 19 seriously, and 291 protesters were arrested. Following these events, trade unions announced another nationwide protest on June 6, marking the 14th wave of demonstrations against the pension reform. The government expressed its desire to address other issues but agreed to meet with unions to reiterate its opposition to the reform and discuss improving workers' conditions.

Following the government's push for pension reform, continuous demonstrations took place, escalating into violent confrontations between protesters and law enforcement on May 1. The Constitutional Council rejected a second referendum attempt on May 3, leading to more protests, including in Paris' financial district. On May 8, despite the ban on gatherings during Macron's Victory Day celebrations, protests occurred in Paris and Lyon, resulting in tear gas usage. Clashes erupted near Montluc prison when Macron visited. Hospital workers protested at Carlton Cannes Hotel on May 19, violating a city-wide protest ban. Throughout these events, Iran's Foreign Ministry called for non-violence, and the government agreed to meet with unions to discuss improving workers' conditions.

After the government's pension reform efforts, demonstrations have been ongoing, escalating into conflicts with law enforcement and violating protest bans. Hospital workers protested at Carlton Cannes Hotel on May 19, and more gatherings occurred in Gannes during the Cannes Film Festival on May 21. On June 6, a large protest took place, leading to flight cancellations at Orly Airport and the temporary occupation of the 2024 Summer Olympics headquarters. Authorities deployed significant law enforcement resources due to increasing violence concerns, which have been noted by various organizations since the application of Article 49.3. This situation evokes memories of the earlier Yellow Vests protests under Macron's presidency.

The Guardian, Reuters, and Euronews have reported on the escalating tensions and growing anger in France, drawing comparisons to the Yellow Vests protests. Protests against the pension reform have been taking place since January, mostly peacefully, but becoming more intense recently with bins set on fire and clashes with police. The protests have been well-attended, and unions, while initially united, have expressed concerns about potentially losing control as more extreme demonstrators become prominent. This situation has led to fears of another wave of violent anti-government protests in France.

The escalating tensions and anger in France, akin to the Yellow Vests protests, have been growing due to the intense pension reform protests. Union leaders, such as Fabrice Coudour (CGT) and Lauren Escure (UNSA), acknowledge the rising prominence of more extreme demonstrators, which they fear might lead to uncontrollable actions and a potential breakdown of order. This situation has resulted in concerns about increased radicalization and the possibility of extensive, violent anti-government protests. Notably, Yellow Vests spokesperson Jerome Rodrigues has declared the goal of defeating the president. Moderate union leaders, including Cyril Chabanier (CFTC) and Laurent Berger (CFDT), have also expressed their concerns about the escalating situation.

The moderate union leaders, Cyril Chabanier (CFTC) and Laurent Berger (CFDT), have expressed their concerns about the escalating violence and radicalization during the pension reform protests in France. They mentioned that growing anger is leading to increased radicalization and subsequent violence. Berger cautioned the government that protests could turn more violent if protesters believe the Yellow Vests have achieved more with violence than peaceful demonstrations by established unions. Both leaders condemned the violence while acknowledging the strong anger present even within their own union ranks. The Guardian reported that officials from the Republican party have been receiving numerous threatening emails, and their office was vandalized, highlighting the escalating tensions and threats of violence.

The leaders of moderate unions, Cyril Chabanier and Laurent Berger, have voiced concerns about rising violence and radicalization during the pension reform protests. They noted that growing anger is leading to increased threats and violence, with officials from the Republican party receiving numerous threatening emails and their office vandalized. This highlights the escalating tensions and threats of violence. In addition, a waste collectors' strike began on March 6, which included a blockade of the city's incinerators and resulted in waste accumulation. The protests have been intense but not large in scale, mainly led by committed left-wing activists, and the strike was extended beyond the original nine days.

A strike by waste collectors, starting from March 6, caused the blockage of the city's incinerators and led to waste accumulation, with thousands of tonnes of garbage left uncollected on Paris streets. Initially planned for nine days, the strike was extended. By March 17, there were approximately 10,000 tonnes of waste, up from 7,600 earlier in the week. Emergency measures were implemented to resume waste collection, but the effectiveness of these measures was contested.

Waste collector strikes, supported by Paris' deputy mayor, have caused a blockage of the city's incinerators, resulting in 10,000 tonnes of garbage accumulating on streets as of March 17. The strikers, who began their action 12 days earlier, are protesting proposed pension reforms that would increase their retirement age from 57 to 59. While private companies have stepped in to collect waste in some areas, the mayor of the ninth district has proposed calling in the military to clear the streets. Despite government attempts to end the strike, the deputy mayor has asserted that demanding strikers to return to work would infringe upon their constitutional right to strike.

Waste collection strikes have spread to other French cities, including Antibes, Rennes, and Le Havre. In Paris, the mayor of the 12th district, Emmanuelle Pierre-Marie, has prioritized collecting food waste due to health concerns. The CGT union leader, Philippe Martinez, encouraged workers to continue striking. The strike ended on March 29th due to decreased participation and police requisitions. There were reports of violent behavior by police during protests, but only a small number of arrests led to charges. The strikes were a response to proposed pension reforms that would increase the retirement age for waste collectors.

The police's actions during the waste collection strikes in France involved instances of violent behavior and mass arrests, with only a few resulting in charges. Many individuals who were not involved in the protests were also detained, including two Austrian children on a school trip. Out of the 292 arrested on March 16th, only nine were charged, while 60 people arrested on March 17th had 34 cases closed and 21 with alternative outcomes, leaving only five at trial. A lawyer, Coline Bouillon, plans to file a collective complaint against the police for arbitrary detention and obstruction of the right to demonstrate, as a large group of people at a conference were rounded up and detained for allegedly preparing violence or concealing their faces.

The police's use of "arbitrary custody" and mass arrests has been criticized by politicians, judges, and lawyers, who argue that these tactics are employed to suppress protest movements. This approach is perceived as a form of repression, as seen in past protests like the gilet jaunes. A judges' union, the Syndicat de la Magistrature (SM), and a lawyer specializing in judiciary repression methods, Raphaël Kempf, share this view. Kempf noted that this is the first time the government has resorted to using criminal law to discourage demonstrators from exercising their right to protest.

Over the past 15 years, there has been a growing "judicialisation of policing," with the police increasingly relying on arrests and criminal laws to manage protests, as observed by Fabien Jobard, a research director at France's National Scientific Research Centre (CNRS). A 2010 law that initially targeted gang violence and incidents at sporting events has been expanded to cover protests, leading to concerns about the use of disproportionate force and mass arrests. Critics argue that this trend is aimed at suppressing protest movements, with Clément Voule, the UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Association, expressing concerns over violent confrontations and arbitrary arrests. However, the Interior Ministry maintains that all arrests are justified and necessary for processing offenses. Overall, the text discusses the shift towards a more legalistic approach to policing protests, which has been met with criticism and concerns over its impact on freedom of association and expression.

The text discusses concerns and developments related to the policing of protests in France. A senior police source mentioned that mass arrests have not been ordered, but individual arrests of high-risk profiles can prevent further disruption. However, increased arrests can strain police resources and potentially escalate tensions. There have been allegations of sexual assault by police during a demonstration in Nantes and excessive use of force by police during protests, as reported by The Guardian and BBC News. Lewis Goodall, a British journalist, also noted police brutality in Paris. The Council of Europe has criticized the use of excessive force by authorities. The protests are politically significant, as they are partly a response to President Macron's proposal to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64. This proposal has been compared to former President Nicolas Sarkozy's 2010 reform, which resulted in widespread strikes and protests. Public opinion polling suggests that Sarkozy's push for reform contributed to voters turning to both the Socialist Party and the far-right National Front in the 2012 presidential election.

The text also notes the potential impact of invoking Article 49.3 on executive approval, citing a tweet from an author of a paper in the academic journal West European Politics. The Guardian has highlighted the broader political dissatisfaction driving the protests, comparing them to the gilet jaunes movement, which began as a protest against fuel tax rises but evolved to reflect a wider lack of trust in the political system.

The Guardian noted a parallel between the current protests and the gilet jaunes movement, which started as opposition to fuel tax increases but broadened to reflect general political discontent. Antoine Bristielle from the Fondation Jean-Jaures think tank suggested that invoking Article 49.3 might be seen as an act of brutality, potentially damaging support for the government and democratic institutions. Before the unsuccessful no-confidence votes, potential alternatives were considered, such as replacing Prime Minister Borne or holding a referendum to let voters decide on the pension reforms.

The no-confidence votes were predicted to likely fail, and even the centrist group LIOT's vote, which had the best chance of gaining support from various political parties, did not succeed because not enough members of the Republicans voted in favor. If the votes had failed, the National Assembly could have been dissolved, leading to new elections, but this was considered unlikely. Another option is a shared-initiative referendum (RIP), which requires the support of one-fifth of both the National Assembly and Senate, as well as signatures from one-tenth of the electorate within nine months.

The text discusses the possibility of a shared-initiative referendum (RIP) to block the pension reforms, which requires support from a portion of the National Assembly, Senate, and signatures from the electorate. This option was brought up by Stéphane Peu, a member of the Communist Party Deputy and NUPES, who claimed they had sufficient support since March 14. If triggered, the reforms would be delayed until the referendum, potentially disrupting Macron's plan to implement changes from September. The text also mentions that NUPES members plan to appeal to the Constitutional Council, as they would have done if the bill had passed through voting.

NUPES is considering using a shared-initiative referendum to block the pension reforms, which, if successful, would delay the implementation of the changes and potentially disrupt Macron's plans. They argue that the reform, which is part of the social security budget, is a legislative rider and unconstitutional, based on the Conseil d'État's warning to the government. NUPES also plans to appeal to the Constitutional Council. Additionally, there have been reports that King Charles III's state visit to France may be disrupted due to ongoing protests, with criticism over the timing and optics of the trip.

NUPES may use a shared-initiative referendum to challenge the pension reforms, while King Charles III's state visit to France faces potential disruption due to ongoing protests. The optics of the King and Queen Consort attending a lavish dinner at Versailles Palace, a symbol of social inequalities and excess, have also been criticized.

Unions announced another national protest on March 28, leading to the postponement of King Charles III's state visit, initially scheduled for March 24-26, to the summer when things settle down. Iran criticized France for allegedly suppressing protests and called for respecting human rights.

The Iranian Foreign Minister, Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, urged France to respect human rights and stop using excessive force against its citizens, echoing criticisms from various human rights groups. These groups, including the French Human Rights League and Human Rights Watch, have accused French authorities of disproportionate and dangerous use of public force, arbitrary deprivation of liberty, and abusive police practices, which could escalate tensions. The National Consultative Commission on Human Rights and the French Defender of Rights have also expressed concerns over these issues.

The French Defender of Rights and human rights organizations like Human Rights Watch, Reporters Without Borders, and the UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Association have criticized France for using disproportionate force, arbitrarily detaining individuals, and engaging in abusive police practices during demonstrations. These actions, they argue, risk escalating tensions and violating the fundamental right to peaceful assembly. The Council of Europe has also condemned France's crackdown on protests, emphasizing that excessive force by state agents is not justified even in response to sporadic acts of violence.
